title: Borrowck panics possibly while analyzing async fns after typeck fails earlier

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Sorry that I cannot reduce the original code for reproduction. However, I will provide as many details as possible. Any guidance for how to reduce the test case is very welcome.

In an `async fn`, obvious things such as `await` on non-`Future`s fails typeck. However, borrowck panics after this. Here is the backtrace info.

### Error output
```
error: internal compiler error: src/librustc_mir/borrow_check/universal_regions.rs:750: cannot convert `ReEmpty(U0)` to a region vid

thread 'rustc' panicked at 'Box<Any>', src/librustc_errors/lib.rs:904:9
stack backtrace:
   0: backtrace::backtrace::libunwind::trace
             at /cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/backtrace-0.3.46/src/backtrace/libunwind.rs:86

note: Some details are omitted, run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=full` for a verbose backtrace.

note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.

note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#bug-reports

note: rustc 1.44.0 (49cae5576 2020-06-01) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

note: compiler flags: -C opt-level=3 -C debuginfo=2 --crate-type lib

note: some of the compiler flags provided by cargo are hidden

query stack during panic:
#0 [mir_borrowck] borrow-checking `state::session::<impl state::Session<G>>::process_session::{{closure}}#0`
#1 [mir_borrowck] borrow-checking `state::session::<impl state::Session<G>>::process_session`
#2 [type_of] processing `state::session::<impl state::Session<G>>::process_session::{{opaque}}#0`
#3 [check_mod_item_types] checking item types in module `state::session`
#4 [analysis] running analysis passes on this crate
end of query stack
```

### Meta

If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

